body: Maybe such method can be added to this can be a part of `RecursiveComparisonAssert`

It will be also good, I will be able to write 

```java
assertThat(book).usingRecursiveComparison().hasNoNullFieldsOrProperties();
```

but from other side method `usingRecursiveComparison` will provide not only comparator but also assertions so can be misunderstood.

Maybe more readable will be renamed `usingRecursiveComparison` -> `usingRecursive`
so we will have:

```java
assertThat(book).usingRecursive().hasNoNullFieldsOrProperties();
assertThat(book).usingRecursive().isEqualTo(anotherBook);
```

or in fluent way

```java
assertThat(book).usingRecursive()
    .hasNoNullFieldsOrProperties()
    .isEqualTo(anotherBook);
```

I agree with @nach-o-man, this could be added to the recursive comparison as mentioned by  @slawekjaranowski 
```java
assertThat(book).usingRecursiveComparison().hasNoNullFieldsOrProperties();
```
I don't think adding `usingRecursive` would be good in the long term, I believe people will be confused when having to decide whether to call or `usingRecursive` or `usingRecursiveComparison`.

What is design decision?
This feature will be very useful for me.
I can try to implement it.

I'm thinking a better way would to apply a predicate to all fields, this is a bit more generic and would apply to your case by giving a predicate like `field -> field != null`.

This is not easy to implement, recursive comparison requires to track already visited objects to avoid infinite cycle where A <-> B.

In your case, how would you treat collection fields? if it is not null, do you want to check the content?

Possibility of applying a predicate to all fields is good idea.

I would to  test collections.

My proposition:

```
   assertThat(book).usingRecursive().allSatisfyFields(filed -> { ... });
```

I look at code and package `org.assertj.core.api.recursive.comparison` has many useful hints and class, maybe some of them can be reused.  But I think recurring walk on fields will be something different that comparing.
So code can be placed in new package `org.assertj.core.api.recursive.walk`

I would also like this feature. Either approach would work for me:
- `.usingRecursiveComparison().hasNoNullFieldsOrProperties();`
- `.usingRecursive().allSatisfyFields(filed -> { ... });` (maybe rename to "allFieldsSatisfy" or similar, for sanity)

but of course the 2nd alternative has more benefits, because we can provide a "null-or-empty" predicate (to also cover collections).

I think this is a crucial feature to be able to avoid false-positives in object graphs.
Is anybody working on this? If not, can I?
Seems to be up for grabs, so I'll give it to you. Thanks, @BenTels!

issue.title: Issue2211 has no null fields or properties recurrence

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
#### Check List:
* Fixes #2211
* Unit tests : YES
* Javadoc with a code example (on API only) : YES
* PR meets the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/assertj/assertj-core/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md)

Following the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/assertj/assertj-core/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) will make it easier for us to review and accept your PR.

My solution is a little different than what was proposed in the original issue. I added a `usingRecursiveAssertion()` rather than adding onto `usingRecursiveComparison()` -- mostly because recursive assertion really isn't comparison at all.

I reused code from recursive comparison where possible, so recursive assertion supports some of the same ignore rules. In addition recursive assertion can be configured to ignore primitives, to include JCL types and can be configured for different ways of handling collections and maps.

I also added a convenience method for asserting not null, because I expect that to be used most frequently.

Interested to hear what you guys think. Please let me know whether the documentation is up to your standard.

body:
Submitted initial solution.

Should I assign this issue to someone else now?
